elements.content: The reaction between disulfonic acid, i.e., 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid (NDS), Cu­(NO3)2­·3H2O, and variety of ditopic pyridine analogues viz., 9,10-bis­((E)-2-(pyridin-4-yl)­vinyl)­anthracene (B4PVA), 9,10-bis­((E)-2-(pyridin-3-yl)­vinyl)­anthracene (B3PVA), and 3,3′-(peroxybis­(methylene))­dipyridine (3PBP), resulted in the formation of salts/metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), i.e., [NDS2–·B4PVA2+·S] (FNP 1a), [NDS2–·3PBP2+­·MeOH­·H2O] (FNP 1b), [Cu·NDS­·B4PVA] (FNP 1c), [Cu·NDS­·B3PVA] (FNP 1d), and [Cu·NDS·3PBP] (FNP 1e), by the diffusion method where S in FNP 1a is a squeezed solvent molecule. Sulfonates with six oxygen atoms are involved in coordination with metal center and formed hydrogen bond interactions. X-ray structural analysis showed supramolecular architecture of the salts/MOFs where ligands act as a linear linker. The approximate particle size was calculated by powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the compounds using the Debye–Scherrer equation. The morphological characterization of the FNPs were performed by using scanning electron microscopy. The emission properties of these salts/MOFs may due the intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) and ligand to metal charge transfer phenomena. These nanocrystals were evaluated in live-cell imaging assays using HeLa and MCF-7 as a model cell-line.

elements.content: In this report, we have designed five fluorescent nanoparticles (FNPs) such as salts or metal−organic frameworks having long-lived luminescent lifetimes and minimal photodamage to living organisms for in vitro bioimaging by using 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid (NDS) and N-heterocyclic ditopic pyridyl based highly fluorescent sensitizer FNPs which show promising cell imaging applications.
elements.clean_text: In this report, we have designed five fluorescent nanoparticles (FNPs) such as salts or metal-organic frameworks having long-lived luminescent lifetimes and minimal photodamage to living organisms for in vitro bioimaging by using 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid (NDS) and N-heterocyclic ditopic pyridyl based highly fluorescent sensitizer FNPs which show promising cell imaging applications.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline porous hybrid inorganic–organic materials prepared from an assembly of metal ions with organic linkers through strong covalent bonds. Their defined porosity and tunable chemical functionality make them attractive for applications like gas storage, catalysis, separation, etc. Apart from their use as bulk materials in the above applications, MOFs are also potential candidates in bioimaging for living cells. However, because of their microporosity (generally, a pore size of <2 nm), the potential applications of these materials are limited. To overcome this limitation, one can either create mesoporous channels within MOFs or reduce the crystals to nanosize.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline porous hybrid inorganic-organic materials prepared from an assembly of metal ions with organic linkers through strong covalent bonds. Their defined porosity and tunable chemical functionality make them attractive for applications like gas storage, catalysis, separation, etc. Apart from their use as bulk materials in the above applications, MOFs are also potential candidates in bioimaging for living cells. However, because of their microporosity (generally, a pore size of <2 nm), the potential applications of these materials are limited. To overcome this limitation, one can either create mesoporous channels within MOFs or reduce the crystals to nanosize.

elements.content: Recently organic salts and inorganic photoactive materials on the nanometer scale have received considerable attention owing to their application in many fields including light-emitting diode, wavelength-tunable lasers, catalysis, solar cells, drug delivery, bioimaging, etc. The majority of nanomaterials are either purely organic (such as liposomes) or inorganic (such as quantum dots) in composition. Furthermore, the external surface of fluorescent MOF nanocrystals also provides the potential to functionalize the core–shell nanostructures for biomedical sensing and imaging. Thus, it is very important to synthesize nanoscale fluorescent MOFs for application in live-cell imaging. In the literature, different methods have been used for the synthesis of nanosized MOFs, like surfactant-mediated hydrothermal syntheses, water-in-oil microemulsions, microwave-assisted solvo-/hydrothermal synthesis, and coordination modulation. Apart from these methods, the key parameters used for the control of particle size and shape still remain a challenge as the introduction of new functionality and maintaining intrinsic features are the main limitation for the use of nanoscale metal–organic frameworks (NMOFs). Although organic nanomaterial and nanoscale metal–organic frameworks (NMOFs)/nanoscale coordination polymers (NCPs) have been used in biomedical applications, still the results in live-cell imaging are not very satisfactory.

elements.content: Luminescent probes are highly recommended for the successful detection of an intracellular cell as they give the intracellular signal noninvasively in live-cell imaging. Besides this property, the fluorescent probes also possess intrinsic advantages over other types of detecting methods in terms of selectivity, sensitivity, and easy application. An increasing number of studies have used NMOFs as molecular imaging probes and drug nanocarriers. Compared with conventional nanocarriers (e.g., organic nanocarriers of lipids/polymers, silica nanomaterials, and inorganic zeolites), NMOFs possess some unique properties that allow them to perform as promising nanoplatforms for bioimaging. The presence of relatively labile metal ligand bonds in NMOFs makes them biodegradable; therefore it rapidly degrades the complex material and deliver the drug or probe.

elements.content: The utilization of the various nanosized MOFs based on iron­(III) carboxylate nanoparticles with different organic linkers and structures (MIL-100, MIL-101) in biomedicine is usual due to their acceptable in vitro and in vivo toxicological results. Iron­(III) carboxylate MOFs show several fascinating features, i.e., high pore volume and tunable pore size for the efficient payloads of entrapped drugs. There are several reports on lanthanide complexes emitting in the NIR because these complexes have exciting properties for biological imaging.

elements.content: In this report, we have designed fluorescent nanoparticles (FNPs) by using 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid (NDS) and N-heterocyclic ditopic pyridyl based highly fluorescent sensitizer (). These FNPs have significantly smaller particle size (∼35–80 nm) and showed important cytotoxicity values (10 μg/mL), which is supposed to be linkers based antitumor activity. It was envisaged that all these FNPs are highly fluorescent and suitable for live-cell imaging. They enter into cells without any further change in functionalization, and the fluorescence property of these nanoparticles can be used for fluorescence-based cell imaging applications.
elements.clean_text: In this report, we have designed fluorescent nanoparticles (FNPs) by using 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid (NDS) and N-heterocyclic ditopic pyridyl based highly fluorescent sensitizer (). These FNPs have significantly smaller particle size (~35-80 nm) and showed important cytotoxicity values (10 μg/mL), which is supposed to be linkers based antitumor activity. It was envisaged that all these FNPs are highly fluorescent and suitable for live-cell imaging. They enter into cells without any further change in functionalization, and the fluorescence property of these nanoparticles can be used for fluorescence-based cell imaging applications.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the reagents and starting materials were of reagent-grade. Anthracene, naphthalene-1,5-disulfonic acid (NDS), triethylphosphite, nicotinaldehyde, and isonicotinaldehyde were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Sweden. Analytically pure metal salt, i.e., Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O was obtained from Himedia, Mumbai, India, and used without further purification. The tetraethyl anthracene-9,10-diylbis(methylene)diphosphonate (ADP) was synthesized according to a literature method.

elements.content: Tetraethylanthracene-9,10-diylbis­(methylene)­diphosphonate (ADP) (6.00 g, 12.53 mmol) was dissolved in 150 mL of THF and cooled the solution at 0 °C followed by the slow addition of NaH (1.20 g, 50.10 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature under nitrogen atmosphere, and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (9.44 mL, 108.60 mmol) was added at 0 °C. The resulting solution was stirred further for 24 h at room temperature. The yellow precipitate was filtered and washed with THF. Yield: 42.0% (2.51 g).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

9,10-Bis((E)-2-(pyridin-4-yl)vinyl)anthracene (B4PVA)

Tetraethylanthracene-9,10-diylbis(methylene)diphosphonate (ADP) (6.00 g, 12.53 mmol) was dissolved in 150 mL of THF and cooled the solution at 0 °C followed by the slow addition of NaH (1.20 g, 50.10 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature under nitrogen atmosphere, and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (9.44 mL, 108.60 mmol) was added at 0 °C. The resulting solution was stirred further for 24 h at room temperature. The yellow precipitate was filtered and washed with THF. Yield: 42.0% (2.51 g).

elements.content:
1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): d (ppm) 8.69 (d, 4H), 8.32 (dd, 4H), 8.15 s, 4H), 7.56 (d, 4H), 7.52 (dd, 4H), 6.90 (d, 2H).

9,10-Bis­((<italic>E</italic>)-2-(pyridin-3-yl)­vinyl)­anthracene (B3PVA)

The compound B3PVA was synthesized by the same procedure as employed for the B4PVA by using nicotinaldehyde (9.44 mL, 108.60 mmol) in place of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde. Yield: 67.0% (3.33 g).

1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): d (ppm) 6.94 (d, 2H), 7.41 (dd, 2H), 7.52 (dd, 4H), 8.04 (t, 4H), 8.37 (dd, 4H), 8.61 (d, 2H), 8.88 (s, 2H).

3,3′-(Peroxybis­(methylene))­dipyridine (3PBP)

Isonicotinaldehyde (5.00 mL, 57.53 mmol) was dissolved in 80 mL of THF, and the solution was cooled at 0 °C followed by the slow addition of NaH (1.38 g, 57.53 mmol). The mixture was stirred in nitrogen atmosphere for 30 min at room temperature. The resultant solution was further stirred under UV light for 12 h at room temperature with continuous stirring. The pale yellow crystalline material was filtered and washed several times with THF. Yield: 68.0% (1.88 g).

Sample Characterization

All the samples were carefully dried under a vacuum for several hours prior to elemental analysis on Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns for all the FNPs were measured on a Bruker D8 diffractometer (CuKα, λ = 1.540 Å) at 296 K. UV–vis absorption spectra were measured in the range 200–800 nm by using UV 1800, Shimadzu UV spectrophotometer with a slit width of 1.0 nm. The fluorescence emission spectra were recorded on a RF-5301PC spectrofluorophotometer (Shimadzu) with the excitation wavelength of 410 nm for FNP 1a, FNP 1c, and FNP 1d, and 300 nm for FNP 1b and FNP 1e with a slit width of 2.5 nm for both the excitation and emission. The fluorescence decay profiles were recorded by exciting the sample at 410 nm in the nanoseconds time domain in solvent DMF using a Horiba Jobin Yvon “fluorocube FL” lifetime system equipped with a new LED (635 nm) source. The DSC and TG analyses were performed using PerkinElmer Pyris Diamond DSC and Pyris Diamond thermogravimetry analyzers, respectively. The sample was heated in nitrogen atmosphere, with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1, and a scan was recorded within the temperature range of 30–600 °C. 1H and 13C NMR spectra for the ligand B4PVA, B3PVA, and 3PBP were recorded in deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) on a JEOL ECX-400-II. Chemical shifts of 1H NMR spectra were given in parts per million (ppm) with respect to TMS. The signal solvent from CDCl3, 7.26 and 77.0 ppm are set as a reference peak in 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra, respectively. Proton coupling patterns are described as singlet (s), doublet (d), triplet (t), quartet (q), and multiplet (m). HRMS were recorded on a Bruker microTOF-Q-II mass spectrometer (ESI-MS).

elements.content: The X-ray data of all FNPs were collected on a Bruker Kappa Apex four circle-CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71070 Å) at 296 K. Structure solution and refinement were done by direct method and developed by conventionally alternating cycles of least-squares refinement on SHELXTL program. SAINT and SADABS software packages were employed for data reductions and absorption corrections, respectively. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were granted to hop on their respective parent atoms according to their positions generated theoretically and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. In FNP 1a and FNP 1c the solvent molecules were highly disordered and was impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models; thereby, the share of partial solvent electron densities was rejected by the SQUEEZE program in PLATON. Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) as deposition Nos. CCDC 1584722–1584726 and 1828635.

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The NMR and HRMS data for ligands B4PVA and B3PVA are very similar to the reported data in the literature. The 1H, 13C NMR, and HRMS data (Figures S1, S2, and S3) suggest the structure of the ligand 3PBP which was further confirmed by single crystal X-ray structure (Figure S4).

elements.content: FNP 1a, 1c, and 1d crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with C2/c space group, whereas FNP 1b crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P21/c space group. FNP 1e crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with P1̅ space group.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description

FNP 1a, 1c, and 1d crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with C2/c space group, whereas FNP 1b crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P21/c space group. FNP 1e crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with P1̅ space group.

elements.content: NDS·B4PVA (FNP 1a) comprised half molecules each of monocationic ligand B4PVA and monoanion NDS in the asymmetric unit (Figure S5). Both the component in the unit cell are connected with each other through charge assisted hydrogen bond interactions N(1)–H­(1N)···O with the bond distance 1.900 Å and extended to a 1D helical structure, which is further linked into the 2D sheet of NDS·B4PVA through C–H···O interactions between anthracene moieties of the B4PVA and sulfonate oxygen of NDS. Subsequently, N–H···O and C–H···O interactions resulted in the generation of two type of cyclic motif along the a-axis (Figure S6). Moreover, the anthracene rings of B4PVA ligand insert into the cavity formed by these interactions between B4PVA and NDS which are extended adjacent sheets into a 3D supramolecular architecture. The framework was stabilized by C–H···π and π···π interactions with the bond distances 2.298 and 3.600 Å respectively between anthracene moieties of one B4PVA, pyridine ring of another B4PVA ligand, resulting in the formation of 1D channel along the c-axis which was occupied by a squeezed solvent molecule (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: NDS⋅B4PVA (FNP 1a) comprised half molecules each of monocationic ligand B4PVA and monoanion NDS in the asymmetric unit (Figure S5). Both the component in the unit cell are connected with each other through charge assisted hydrogen bond interactions N(1)-H(1N)⋅⋅⋅O with the bond distance 1.900 Å and extended to a 1D helical structure, which is further linked into the 2D sheet of NDS⋅B4PVA through C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions between anthracene moieties of the B4PVA and sulfonate oxygen of NDS. Subsequently, N-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions resulted in the generation of two type of cyclic motif along the a-axis (Figure S6). Moreover, the anthracene rings of B4PVA ligand insert into the cavity formed by these interactions between B4PVA and NDS which are extended adjacent sheets into a 3D supramolecular architecture. The framework was stabilized by C-H⋅⋅⋅π and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions with the bond distances 2.298 and 3.600 Å respectively between anthracene moieties of one B4PVA, pyridine ring of another B4PVA ligand, resulting in the formation of 1D channel along the c-axis which was occupied by a squeezed solvent molecule (Figure S7).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of solvate FNP 1b exhibited one 3PBP ligand, one crystallographic dependent NDS molecule, one water and methanol molecule as shown in . The structure is sustained by transfer of proton from NDS molecule to 3PBP ligand. The formation of charge assisted hydrogen bond was not observed in this case. Therefore, 3PBP self-assembled and formed the 1D tape (Figure S8) through hydrogen bond (N1–H1A···N2, 1.891 Å) between two 3PBP ligand. There is no direct interaction between both the ligands. Furthermore, the 1D tape of sulfonates is extended to a 2D sheet using C5–H46···O3 interaction (bond distance 2.652 Å) between the naphthyl ring of NDS and sulfonated oxygen. Structural analysis revealed that the interaction of neighboring 2D sheet via C–H···O interaction through the proton on pyridyl ring of 3PBP in 1D chain and the sulfonate oxygen from 2D sheet of NDS raises the dimensionality from a 2D to 3D supramolecular organic framework (Figure S9). Various intermolecular hydrogen bonding is involved in this solvate and formed the tetramer motif via O6–H45···O4 (1.657 Å) and O6–H3W···O5 (2.024 Å) interactions.

elements.content: Cu·NDS·B4PVA (FNP 1c) possesses a 2-fold interpenetrated structure. The asymmetric unit of FNP 1c consists of one Cu­(II) center coordinated with two crystallographically dependent B4PVA ligand, half molecule NDS, and two THF molecules. The local coordination environment around the Cu­(II) center is depicted in . The Cu­(II) is coordinated equatorially by four nitrogen atoms of the pyridyl group of bidentate B4PVA ligand, and the axial position is occupied by sulfonate oxygen atoms of NDS resulting in a slightly distorted octahedral geometry. The average bond distance of Cu­(II)–N1, Cu­(II)–N2, and Cu­(II)–N3 lies in the ranges of 1.983–2.062 Å, whereas the Cu­(II)–O1 bond distance is 2.733 Å, which is very similar to reported data for copper complexes. The N–Cu­(II)–N and angle around the metal center ranges from 88.99° to 95.30°. Further the structural analysis revealed that the Cu­(II) ion coordinated by bidentate B4PVA ligand at the equatorial position extend the structure to a 2D layer structure with a larger cavity. The axially coordinated sulfonate oxygens extended the 2D layered structure into a 3D porous structure with rectangular cavities as shown in . A number of weak interactions viz., C–H···O (2.530 Å) between olefinic proton of B4PVA and sulfonate oxygen of NDS and C–H···π (2.887 Å) interaction between the proton present at the pyridyl ring of B4PVA and π-electron cloud of naphthyl ring of NDS are also involved. Further, the 3D network interpenetrated into the cavity of another 3D framework led to the formation of a 2-fold interpenetrated slightly porous structure (), and the resultant cavity is occupied by THF molecule. THF connected through the host framework with C–H···O (2.658 Å) and C–H···π (2.392 Å) interactions.

elements.content: Cu­(II) displayed a regular octahedral geometry by linking four equatorial N atoms of B3PVA ligands and two oxygen atoms of axial NDS molecules. Like in FNP 1c, the Cu­(II) is coordinated by bidentate B3PVA at the equatorial position extended into a 2D layer, but there is a large difference in bond length of axially coordinated oxygen atom from sulfonate anion (Figure S10). The average bond distance of Cu­(II)–N1 and Cu­(II)–O1 is 2.039 and 2.393 Å respectively, and the N–Cu­(II)–N angle around the metal center ranges from 85.74° to 92.67°. The difference in bond length of the axially coordinated atom in FNP 1c and FNP 1d may be due to the C–H···π interactions between the π-electron cloud of the naphthyl ring in NDS. The naphthyl ring of NDS is slightly tilted in the cavity of the 2D layer present in FNP 1d and prevents the framework from the interpenetration. The adjacent 2D layer connected through the NDS molecule and led to the formation of 3D metal–organic frameworks with small rectangular cavities (). It also showed C–H···O, C–H···S, and π···π interactions along with C–H···π such as C33–H33A···O1, 2.581 Å; C33–H33A···O1, 2.381 Å, C10–H10A···O3 2.490; C10–H10A···S1, 2.912 Å and π···π, 3.220 Å interaction between two pyridyl rings.

elements.content: Structural analysis of FNP 1e revealed that the asymmetric unit consists of one Cu­(II) center, one-half molecule of 3PBP, half molecule of uncoordinated NDS, two coordinated water molecules, and two lattice water molecules, and one of the water molecule presents on a special axis. As shown in Figure S11, the Cu ion adopts regular octahedral geometry, the two equatorial position are coordinated with 3PBP, and all other equatorial and axial positions are occupied by water molecules. The bond length of Cu–N is 2.008 Å, and Cu–O is in the range of 1.988–2.453 Å. Each 3PBP links Cu­(II) ions through pyridyl nitrogen (N1A) and leads to the formation of a 1D chain. The sulfonate oxygen of lattice NDS involves hydrogen bonding with coordinated water molecules through O–H···O and C–H···O interactions and resulted in the formation of a layered structure (Figure S12).

elements.content: In order to check the purity of bulk sample of five nanosize salts/MOFs, PXRD measurements of 1a–1e were performed to confirm whether the crystal structures of nanoparticles are the actual model of their respective bulk materials, and it was found that the peaks for synthesized nanoparticles are in good agreement with the simulated one (Figure S13).

elements.content: The morphological characterization of nanoscale salts/NMOFs was performed by using SEM. The SEM image displayed the self-assembly of B4PVA and 3PBP with NDS into regular block and rod shape morphology respectively, whereas NMOFs, i.e., 1c, 1d, 1e, showed an irregular shape of particles (Figures S14 and S15). Further, their approximate particle size was calculated by the PXRD pattern of the compounds using the Debye–Scherrer equation: τ = K λ / β cos ⁡ θ
elements.clean_text:
Morphological Study

The morphological characterization of nanoscale salts/NMOFs was performed by using SEM. The SEM image displayed the self-assembly of B4PVA and 3PBP with NDS into regular block and rod shape morphology respectively, whereas NMOFs, i.e., 1c, 1d, 1e, showed an irregular shape of particles (Figures S14 and S15). Further, their approximate particle size was calculated by the PXRD pattern of the compounds using the Debye-Scherrer equation:    τ = K λ / β  cos ⁡ θ

elements.content: In the PXRD pattern, we pick the strongest intensity peak of the salts/MOFs to specify the influence of particle size for PXRD. The full width half maxima (fwhm) of the peak at 4.14, 10.44, and 4.89 are 0.11, 0.15, and 0.23 for 1a, 1c, and 1d respectively, whereas 3PBP salt and MOF showed almost a similar fwhm value 0.10 at the peak 9.58 and 5.90 respectively. Therefore, the particles size of 1b and 1e are approximately the same. The larger particle size can achieve the smaller full width half maxima value. According to the Debye–Scherrer formula the size of the nanoparticles of 1a, 1b, 1c, 1d, and 1e was <100 nm, which makes these particles suitable for the application in live-cell imaging. The development of fluorescent nanoparticles for biomedicines is still scarcely reported, and only in recent years has some progress been made in this direction.

elements.content: The emission spectra of B4PVA, B3PVA, and 3PBP and their respective salts/NMOFs were measured at room temperature. The emissions for the fluorescent linkers B4PVA, B3PVA with a π-conjugated backbone have been observed with the emission wavelength at 558 nm and for the linker 3PBP emission wavelength at 356 nm. Hence the strongest emission of the fluorescent linkers is usually from the excited singlet state to singlet ground state with the transition n → π* or π → π* in nature. The excitation spectra of FNP 1b and FNP 1c are attained by monitoring the emission at 558 nm and are dominated by broad band centered at about 487–655 nm upon excitation at 410 nm (Figures S16, S17, and S18). In comparison with their respective fluorescent linker B4PVA, B3PVA, the quenching in FNP 1a and FNP 1b marked blue shift is presumably due to the multitude of weak interactions, such as hydrogen bonding and π-stacking in FNP 1a and unique coordination of B4PVA and acid coligand NDS linkers to the metal centers, whereas enhancement in FNP 1c was observed with a large blue shift of the peak which may be due to the more rigid coordination of the 3-pyridyl ring of B3PVA ligand and acid coligand NDS to the Cu­(II) center. The excitation spectra of FNP 1c and FNP 1d are attained by monitoring the emission at 356 nm upon excitation at 300 nm and are dominated by a broad band centered at about 375–445 nm in the close proximity to the ultraviolet region. Compared to the 3PBP ligand, the enhancement in fluorescence of FNP 1d and FNP 1e was observed, whereas a large enhancement in fluorescence intensity was observed for MOF nanomaterial FNP 1e with respect to the 3PBP ligand. This may be due to the conformational rigidity of the ligand, thus reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand π → π* excited state. Further fluorescent properties of nanocrystals encouraged us to use these particles for live-cell imaging.

Emission Spectra

The emission spectra of B4PVA, B3PVA, and 3PBP and their respective salts/NMOFs were measured at room temperature. The emissions for the fluorescent linkers B4PVA, B3PVA with a π-conjugated backbone have been observed with the emission wavelength at 558 nm and for the linker 3PBP emission wavelength at 356 nm. Hence the strongest emission of the fluorescent linkers is usually from the excited singlet state to singlet ground state with the transition n → π* or π → π* in nature. The excitation spectra of FNP 1b and FNP 1c are attained by monitoring the emission at 558 nm and are dominated by broad band centered at about 487-655 nm upon excitation at 410 nm (Figures S16, S17, and S18). In comparison with their respective fluorescent linker B4PVA, B3PVA, the quenching in FNP 1a and FNP 1b marked blue shift is presumably due to the multitude of weak interactions, such as hydrogen bonding and π-stacking in FNP 1a and unique coordination of B4PVA and acid coligand NDS linkers to the metal centers, whereas enhancement in FNP 1c was observed with a large blue shift of the peak which may be due to the more rigid coordination of the 3-pyridyl ring of B3PVA ligand and acid coligand NDS to the Cu(II) center. The excitation spectra of FNP 1c and FNP 1d are attained by monitoring the emission at 356 nm upon excitation at 300 nm and are dominated by a broad band centered at about 375-445 nm in the close proximity to the ultraviolet region. Compared to the 3PBP ligand, the enhancement in fluorescence of FNP 1d and FNP 1e was observed, whereas a large enhancement in fluorescence intensity was observed for MOF nanomaterial FNP 1e with respect to the 3PBP ligand. This may be due to the conformational rigidity of the ligand, thus reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand π → π* excited state. Further fluorescent properties of nanocrystals encouraged us to use these particles for live-cell imaging.

elements.content: The excited state information on the fluorescent nanosize salts/MOFs was measured by fluorescence lifetimes (τF), and the corresponding decay curves are shown in Figures S19 and S20. Their fluorescence decay profiles were recorded with excitation and emission wavelength 410 and 558 nm for the salts or NMOFs of B4PVA and B3PVA ligands, whereas for the salts and NMOF of ligand 3PBP, the same was recorded with excitation and emission wavelengths of 300 and 445 nm, respectively. All the fluorescence lifetimes profiles were obtained by fitting the decay profiles in three-exponential form, and the calculated results are tabulated in Table S5. The FNP 1a and FNP 1b has a tow component of (τF) 2.01 and 2.56 ns, respectively. Compared with the NMOFs, i.e., FNP 1c, FNP 1d, and FNP 1e, for which tow components are 3.19, 3.24, and 4.73 ns respectively, the shorter fluorescence lifetime for salts, i.e., FNP 1a and FNP 1b, was observed. The π–π stacking geometries in anthracene fluorophores observed in FNP 1c and FNP 1d favor the formation of ring aggregates, which are further responsible for longer fluorescence lifetimes for NMOFs in comparison to their respective salts.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Lifetime

The excited state information on the fluorescent nanosize salts/MOFs was measured by fluorescence lifetimes (τF), and the corresponding decay curves are shown in Figures S19 and S20. Their fluorescence decay profiles were recorded with excitation and emission wavelength 410 and 558 nm for the salts or NMOFs of B4PVA and B3PVA ligands, whereas for the salts and NMOF of ligand 3PBP, the same was recorded with excitation and emission wavelengths of 300 and 445 nm, respectively. All the fluorescence lifetimes profiles were obtained by fitting the decay profiles in three-exponential form, and the calculated results are tabulated in Table S5. The FNP 1a and FNP 1b has a tow component of (τF) 2.01 and 2.56 ns, respectively. Compared with the NMOFs, i.e., FNP 1c, FNP 1d, and FNP 1e, for which tow components are 3.19, 3.24, and 4.73 ns respectively, the shorter fluorescence lifetime for salts, i.e., FNP 1a and FNP 1b, was observed. The π-π stacking geometries in anthracene fluorophores observed in FNP 1c and FNP 1d favor the formation of ring aggregates, which are further responsible for longer fluorescence lifetimes for NMOFs in comparison to their respective salts.

elements.content: To examine the thermal stability of 1a–1e, TG analyses was carried out, and it was found that FNP 1c and 1d showed almost a similar stability behavior toward thermal decomposition (Figures S21 and S22). It was analyzed that the NDS salt with 3PBP are stable up to 220 °C. In contrast to FNP 1b, FNP 1a was more stable as it represented a more stable framework and hence decomposes around 280 °C. The first mass loss may be for methanol molecule which starts at 80 °C and completes around 120 °C. Later mass loss nearly at 280 °C corresponds to the loss of the organic part of the sulfonic acid. In the case of FNP 1a, the first mass loss corresponds to a discharge of methanol molecule around 84 °C with a loss of 3.84% (experimental) and 3.96% observed, and a second mass loss accounts for the release of water molecules around at 120 °C with a mass loss of 3.43%. The next weight loss at 227 °C attributed to the loss of the organic component of the sulfonic acid.
elements.clean_text:
Themogravimetric Analysis

To examine the thermal stability of 1a-1e, TG analyses was carried out, and it was found that FNP 1c and 1d showed almost a similar stability behavior toward thermal decomposition (Figures S21 and S22). It was analyzed that the NDS salt with 3PBP are stable up to 220 °C. In contrast to FNP 1b, FNP 1a was more stable as it represented a more stable framework and hence decomposes around 280 °C. The first mass loss may be for methanol molecule which starts at 80 °C and completes around 120 °C. Later mass loss nearly at 280 °C corresponds to the loss of the organic part of the sulfonic acid. In the case of FNP 1a, the first mass loss corresponds to a discharge of methanol molecule around 84 °C with a loss of 3.84% (experimental) and 3.96% observed, and a second mass loss accounts for the release of water molecules around at 120 °C with a mass loss of 3.43%. The next weight loss at 227 °C attributed to the loss of the organic component of the sulfonic acid.

elements.content: On the other hand, FNP 1c and FNP 1e were stable up to 340 °C and showed almost similar stability, whereas FNP 1d was stable up to 430 °C which may be due to the formation of a stable framework in the case of FNP 1d. The primary mass loss attributed to the loss of extra framework residual solvent molecules present in their respective lattice. The next loss represents the loss of organic component of the metal–organic framework.

elements.content: MCF-7 (human breast adenocarcinoma) and HeLa (human cervical adenocarcinoma) cell lines were purchased from National Centre for Cell Sciences (NCCS), Pune, India. Both the cell lines were maintained in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% heat inactivated fetal bovine serum and 1% antibiotic mix (100 U/mL of penicillin and 100 μg/mL streptomycin) at 37 °C in CO2 incubator.
elements.clean_text:
Cell Culture

MCF-7 (human breast adenocarcinoma) and HeLa (human cervical adenocarcinoma) cell lines were purchased from National Centre for Cell Sciences (NCCS), Pune, India. Both the cell lines were maintained in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% heat inactivated fetal bovine serum and 1% antibiotic mix (100 U/mL of penicillin and 100 μg/mL streptomycin) at 37 °C in CO2 incubator.

elements.content: MTT assay was accomplished as portrayed previously (Mossman, 1986). Briefly, 5 × 103 MCF-7/HeLA cells per well were seeded in 96-well plates. Further, cells were treated with 1, 10, and 100 μg/mL of FNP 1a, FNP 1b, FNP 1c, FNP 1d, and FNP 1e dissolved in DMSO/H2O (v/v = 1:9). After incubation for 48 h the cultures were analyzed by MTT ([3-(4,5-dimethyl-2-thiazolyl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide]) assay by the addition of 10 μL of 5 mg/mL MTT and further incubating at 37 °C for 4 h. The MTT-containing medium was then aspirated and precipitated formazan crystals were dissolved in 200 μL of DMSO. The absorbance was measured on a FLUO star optima Plate Reader (BMG Labtech, Germany) at 570 nm. The cell viability percentage was calculated by following formula: percentage cell viability = ( mean OD of treated cells / mean OD of untreated cells ) × 100
elements.clean_text:
Cell Viability Assay

MTT assay was accomplished as portrayed previously (Mossman, 1986). Briefly, 5 × 103 MCF-7/HeLA cells per well were seeded in 96-well plates. Further, cells were treated with 1, 10, and 100 μg/mL of FNP 1a, FNP 1b, FNP 1c, FNP 1d, and FNP 1e dissolved in DMSO/H2O (v/v = 1:9). After incubation for 48 h the cultures were analyzed by MTT ([3-(4,5-dimethyl-2-thiazolyl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide]) assay by the addition of 10 μL of 5 mg/mL MTT and further incubating at 37 °C for 4 h. The MTT-containing medium was then aspirated and precipitated formazan crystals were dissolved in 200 μL of DMSO. The absorbance was measured on a FLUO star optima Plate Reader (BMG Labtech, Germany) at 570 nm. The cell viability percentage was calculated by following formula:    percentage cell viability =  ( mean OD of treated cells / mean OD of untreated cells )  × 100

elements.content: 5 × 104 MCF-7/HeLa cells were seeded on each coverslip placed in the well of 12 well plates and incubated for 24 h. Thereafter cells were treated with FNP 1a, FNP 1b, FNP 1c, FNP 1d, and FNP 1e solution in five respective wells for 1 h. After 1 h incubation, the probe medium of each well was removed, and the cells were washed two times by PBS. Thereafter the cells were visualized under a Confocal laser scanning microscope (LSM 780, Carl Zeiss, Germany).
elements.clean_text:
Confocal Microscopy

5 × 104 MCF-7/HeLa cells were seeded on each coverslip placed in the well of 12 well plates and incubated for 24 h. Thereafter cells were treated with FNP 1a, FNP 1b, FNP 1c, FNP 1d, and FNP 1e solution in five respective wells for 1 h. After 1 h incubation, the probe medium of each well was removed, and the cells were washed two times by PBS. Thereafter the cells were visualized under a Confocal laser scanning microscope (LSM 780, Carl Zeiss, Germany).

Statistical Analysis

Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation (SD) of triplicate independent experiments and statistically evaluated using one-way ANOVA and followed by Tukey post hoc test using Graph Pad Prism 6 (Graph Pad Software, San Diego, CA, USA). A p-value of less than 0.05 was measured to be statistically significant.

elements.content: In order to show its application in biological samples, we performed an experiment to evaluate the nanocrystal in live-cell imaging assays using HeLa and MCF-7 as a model cell line. First, the cytotoxicity of all the fluorescent nanocrystals was determined by using standard methyl thiayl tetrazolium (MTT) assay. It must be assumed that the viability of unprocessed HeLa and MCF-7 cells was assumed to be 100%. The MTT assay results showed minimal cytotoxicity at the concentration of 10 μg/mL toward cell proliferation; up to 100% HeLa cell and MCF-7 were alive as shown in and . The toxicity demonstrated by these FNPs is equal to or significantly less than the toxicity of various other MOF formulations presently being developed for bioimaging or drug delivery.
elements.clean_text:
Application of Fluorescent Nanoparticles (FNPs) in Biological System

In order to show its application in biological samples, we performed an experiment to evaluate the nanocrystal in live-cell imaging assays using HeLa and MCF-7 as a model cell line. First, the cytotoxicity of all the fluorescent nanocrystals was determined by using standard methyl thiayl tetrazolium (MTT) assay. It must be assumed that the viability of unprocessed HeLa and MCF-7 cells was assumed to be 100%. The MTT assay results showed minimal cytotoxicity at the concentration of 10 μg/mL toward cell proliferation; up to 100% HeLa cell and MCF-7 were alive as shown in  and . The toxicity demonstrated by these FNPs is equal to or significantly less than the toxicity of various other MOF formulations presently being developed for bioimaging or drug delivery.

elements.content: Next the confocal fluorescence and brightfield images of HeLa and MCF-7 cells were determined by laser scanning confocal microscopy (λexc = 410 nm), and for HeLa cell and MCF-7 cells incubated with 10 μg/mL of each FNP 1a, FNP 1b, FNP 1c, FNP 1d, and FNP 1e for 1 h at 37 °C, a clear strong fluorescence signal in the green channel was observed ( and ). It means FNPs are quick to respond to intracellular cell imaging under ambient conditions. In contrast, the individual difference in fluorescence intensities in HeLa and MCF-7 cell confirmed that the fluorescent nanoparticles (FNPs) are membrane-permeable.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized five fluorescent nanosized salts/NMOFs of NDS with various highly fluorescent pyridyl analogues, i.e., B4PVA, B3PVA, and 3PBP by the diffusion method. The approximate size and exact morphology of the salts and NMOFs were analyzed by SEM images which displayed the self-assembly of B4PVA and 3PBP with NDS into regular block and rod shaped morphology respectively, whereas their respective MOF i.e., FNP 1c, 1d, and 1e, showed an irregular shape of particles, and the particles are approximately nano in size (lesser than 100 nm). We have also calculated the approximate size of the FNPs from the Debye–Scherrer formula. These FNPs have highly fluorescent behavior and are suitable for biological applications arising from their pyridylvinyl-containing MOF scaffolds. Upon incubation of these fluorescent nanoparticles with the HeLa and MCF-7 cell line, they showed a lesser cytotoxic effect at the concentration of 10 μg/mL, indicating a high degree of biocompatibility of these FNPs. HeLa cells and MCF-7 cells incubated with 10 μg/mL of each FNP 1a, FNP 1b, FNP 1c, FNP 1d, and FNP 1e for 1 h at 37 °C showed a clear strong fluorescence signal in the green channel.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have synthesized five fluorescent nanosized salts/NMOFs of NDS with various highly fluorescent pyridyl analogues, i.e., B4PVA, B3PVA, and 3PBP by the diffusion method. The approximate size and exact morphology of the salts and NMOFs were analyzed by SEM images which displayed the self-assembly of B4PVA and 3PBP with NDS into regular block and rod shaped morphology respectively, whereas their respective MOF i.e., FNP 1c, 1d, and 1e, showed an irregular shape of particles, and the particles are approximately nano in size (lesser than 100 nm). We have also calculated the approximate size of the FNPs from the Debye-Scherrer formula. These FNPs have highly fluorescent behavior and are suitable for biological applications arising from their pyridylvinyl-containing MOF scaffolds. Upon incubation of these fluorescent nanoparticles with the HeLa and MCF-7 cell line, they showed a lesser cytotoxic effect at the concentration of 10 μg/mL, indicating a high degree of biocompatibility of these FNPs. HeLa cells and MCF-7 cells incubated with 10 μg/mL of each FNP 1a, FNP 1b, FNP 1c, FNP 1d, and FNP 1e for 1 h at 37 °C showed a clear strong fluorescence signal in the green channel.

Tetraethylanthracene-9,10-diylbis­(methylene)­diphosphonate (ADP) (6.00 g, 12.53 mmol) was dissolved in 150 mL of THF and cooled the solution at 0 °C followed by the slow addition of NaH (1.20 g, 50.10 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature under nitrogen atmosphere, and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (9.44 mL, 108.60 mmol) was added at 0 °C. The resulting solution was stirred further for 24 h at room temperature. The yellow precipitate was filtered and washed with THF. Yield: 42.0% (2.51 g).

NDS·3PBP (FNP <bold>1b</bold>)

FNP 1b was synthesized by the same procedure as employed for FNP 1a by using ligand, 3PBP (0.12 g, 0.55 mmol) in place of B4PVA. Yield: 66.0% (0.18 g).

Cu·NDS·B4PVA (FNP <bold>1c</bold>)

The aqueous mixture of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.13 g, 0.55 mmol) and NDS (0.20 g, 0.55 mmol) was layered onto THF solution of ligand B4PVA (0.21 g, 0.55 mmol) with the layer separation of DMF. The brown-colored crystals appeared on the walls of crystallization tube were filtered, and washed with water and THF. Yield: 53.8% (0.07 g).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

9,10-Bis((E)-2-(pyridin-4-yl)vinyl)anthracene (B4PVA)

Tetraethylanthracene-9,10-diylbis(methylene)diphosphonate (ADP) (6.00 g, 12.53 mmol) was dissolved in 150 mL of THF and cooled the solution at 0 °C followed by the slow addition of NaH (1.20 g, 50.10 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature under nitrogen atmosphere, and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (9.44 mL, 108.60 mmol) was added at 0 °C. The resulting solution was stirred further for 24 h at room temperature. The yellow precipitate was filtered and washed with THF. Yield: 42.0% (2.51 g).

Elemental Anal. Calcd % for C38H28N2O6S2: C, 67.84; H, 4.19; N, 4.16; S, 9.53. Found: C, 67.73; H, 4.05; N, 4.04; S, 9.41.

NDS⋅3PBP (FNP 1b)

FNP 1b was synthesized by the same procedure as employed for FNP 1a by using ligand, 3PBP (0.12 g, 0.55 mmol) in place of B4PVA. Yield: 66.0% (0.18 g).

Elemental Anal. Calcd For C22H18N2O8S2: C, 52.58; H, 3.61; N, 5.57; S, 12.76. Found: C, 52.65; H, 3.46; N, 5.46; S, 12.58.

Cu⋅NDS⋅B4PVA (FNP 1c)

The aqueous mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.13 g, 0.55 mmol) and NDS (0.20 g, 0.55 mmol) was layered onto THF solution of ligand B4PVA (0.21 g, 0.55 mmol) with the layer separation of DMF. The brown-colored crystals appeared on the walls of crystallization tube were filtered, and washed with water and THF. Yield: 53.8% (0.07 g).

cln_elements.content: To examine the thermal stability of 1a–1e, TG analyses was carried out, and it was found that FNP 1c and 1d showed almost a similar stability behavior toward thermal decomposition (Figures S21 and S22). It was analyzed that the NDS salt with 3PBP are stable up to 220 °C. In contrast to FNP 1b, FNP 1a was more stable as it represented a more stable framework and hence decomposes around 280 °C. The first mass loss may be for methanol molecule which starts at 80 °C and completes around 120 °C. Later mass loss nearly at 280 °C corresponds to the loss of the organic part of the sulfonic acid. In the case of FNP 1a, the first mass loss corresponds to a discharge of methanol molecule around 84 °C with a loss of 3.84% (experimental) and 3.96% observed, and a second mass loss accounts for the release of water molecules around at 120 °C with a mass loss of 3.43%. The next weight loss at 227 °C attributed to the loss of the organic component of the sulfonic acid.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Themogravimetric Analysis

To examine the thermal stability of 1a-1e, TG analyses was carried out, and it was found that FNP 1c and 1d showed almost a similar stability behavior toward thermal decomposition (Figures S21 and S22). It was analyzed that the NDS salt with 3PBP are stable up to 220 °C. In contrast to FNP 1b, FNP 1a was more stable as it represented a more stable framework and hence decomposes around 280 °C. The first mass loss may be for methanol molecule which starts at 80 °C and completes around 120 °C. Later mass loss nearly at 280 °C corresponds to the loss of the organic part of the sulfonic acid. In the case of FNP 1a, the first mass loss corresponds to a discharge of methanol molecule around 84 °C with a loss of 3.84% (experimental) and 3.96% observed, and a second mass loss accounts for the release of water molecules around at 120 °C with a mass loss of 3.43%. The next weight loss at 227 °C attributed to the loss of the organic component of the sulfonic acid.
